1. Innovation in World Civilization.info:
1a. [32,000-16,000 BC]
 Cro-Magnon artists painted thousands of pictures of animals on the walls of the Pyrenees Mountains.

1b. [768–814 AD]
 Charlemagne unites most of Europe and promoted the spread of Chrisianity throughout his pagan empire.

1c. [3000 BC]
 Start of the Bronze age which saw pictographic systems of writing. Also in Sumer there were early studies of astronomy, metrology, and mathematics.

2. Medieval Transformations.info:
2a. [1304 AD]
The Cloth Hall is completed in the city of Ypres which "testifies to the wealth and influence of the Flemish woolen industry" [Daly, Chapter 2, Construction Boom, 7].

2b. [1322 AD]
The grandiose Palazzo Vecchio was completed in Florence to serve as a town hall for expanding commerce. This trend of building exuberant meeting places was common among the rich northern Italian cities.

2c. [1000's AD]
Many settlements sprung up around main land Europe becuase anyone with a castle and a few knights could own territory. This was only viable because at this time every pety leader did not have to swear loyalty to a king.

3. Papal Revolution.info:
3a. [1049-1109 AD]
The amount of monastaries in Cluncy rose from 60 to 2000. This was a direct cause of new administation Leo IX who supported the reformation.

3b. [927 AD]
A bishop called Le Puy threatened authorities in south central France to keep the peace or else they will be excommunicated.

3c. [1080 AD]
The University of Bologna was founded in order to teach legal practitionars. This school was the first degree-granting school for higher learning in all of Europe.

4. Military Revolutions.info:
4a. [336-323 BC]
Alexander the Great's campaigns and territories taken from the Persians during war.

4b. [1600 BC]
The Shang tribe establishes dominance in the northern China Yello River basin thanks to the tribe's mastery of the chariot.

4c. [1066 AD]
"Duke William of Normandy invaded and conquered England by sea"(Daly, Medival Warfare, 5).

5. Discovery of the World.info:
5a. [1097 AD]
The real First Crusade starts in Constantinople which is located present-day Istanbul, Tureky.

5b. [1271 AD]
Marco Polo travels to modern day the court of Kubalai Khan with his father and brother, located in present-day Beijing.

5c. [1415 AD]
Prince Henry the Navigator led an assault on Ceuta, a port off the coast of Morocco across the Strait of Gibraltar.

6. Explosion of the Printed World.info:
6a. [1638 AD]
Stephen Daye contructs and operates the first printing press in North America at Harvard college.

6b. [1458]
King Charles VII sent spies to France to spy on printing craftsman whom had worked with Gutenberg.

6c. [1593]
Spanish colonists in the Philippines using wood-block printing distribute the first book in Southeast Asia.

7. The Reformation.info:
7a. [1525 AD]
Tyndale translates the bible from Greek to English in Germany because he feared religious persecution in England.

7b. [1433 AD]
The church council of Basel reached an agreement which meant that the Hussites and Bohemians could both be together in the Western Catholicism.

7c. [1515 AD]
Pope Leo X launches a big campaign to build the Basilica of St Peter because the church had recently raised the funds to do so.

8. Scientific Revolutions.info:
8a. [1869 AD]
Dmitrii Mendeleev devises the periodic table of elements.

8b. [1766 AD]
Hydrogen is discovered in England by Henry Cavendish.

8c. [1828]
Jöns Jacob Berzelius invents the modern chemical notation and published a table with the weights of known elements.

9. Commercial Revolutions.info:
9a. [1750-1800 AD]
The number of banks go from fewer than 30 to 70 in London.

9b. [1721 AD]
France founds its first stock exchange to try and compete with the other countries finicial industries.

9c. [1615 AD]
Coffee first appears in Venice from the Islamic world where is starts to spread around Europe.

10. Political Revolutions.info:
10a. [1587-1625 AD]
Maurice of Nassau acted as the main political and military leader uniting multiple provinces in Holland.

10b. [1302 AD]
"Philip the Fair convened France’s first national assembly in 1302 to unite towns and nobles with the monarchy"(Daly, Foundations of Liberty, 12)

10c. [1773 AD]
The Boston Tea Party occurs where American colonists protest British rule by dumping tea from ships into the ocean.

11. Industrial Revolution.info:
11a. [1779 AD]
Samuel Compton invents the "spinning mule" which spun thread thick enough to sustain large scale production.

11b. [1820 AD]
Boulton and Watt devise a lighting system utilizing coal and lights Paris with their new innovation.

11c. [1835 AD]
First major rail service in Massachusetts opens from Boston to Lowell.

12. Technological Revolution.info:
12a. [1822 AD]
William Underwood founds the first successful canning buisness (William Underwood Company) selling canned goods and condiments to people in Boston.

12b. [1847 AD]
The Fry Family invents and markets chocolate bars, among many other chocolate treats, in Bristol England.

12c. [1847-1863 AD]
Alfred Nobel invents and patents important explosive materials such as nitroglycerin and dynamite.

13. Crises of the West.info:
13a. [1939 AD]
Germany invades Poland on September 1st which percipitated the start of World War II.

13b. [1941 AD]
Russia joins World War II after Germany and Japan lauch an offensive on both their borders.

13c. [1950 AD]
Russian backed North Korea invades Pro-US South Korea starting the first or many proxy wars between the Russians and the United States.

14. Social Revolutions.info:
14a. [1800's AD]
English woman invent the modern novel with great writers such as Jane Austen, Mary Ann Evans, and many more.

14b. [1919 AD]
36 of the 48 states ratify the 18th amendment which prohibited the creation, sale, and transportation of alcohol.

14b. [1792 AD]
Mary Wollstonecraft, an early feminist and philosopher, wrote "Vidication of the Rights of Women" where she argued against the inequalities of the modern world.

General History.info:
[1636 AD]
Harvard is founded in Cambridge, Massachusetts and became the home to countless of the best minds in science for years to come.

[1945 AD]
The United States drops the atomic bombs on Japanes cities Hiroshima and Nagasaki ending World War II, marking the first time in history any civilisation used an atomic bomb.

[1440 AD]
Johannes Gutenberg invents the printing press in Germany which is the single most important innovation in the modern age.

[1914 AD]
Franz Ferdinand of Austria is assassinated which causes a series of events leading to the first world war.

[1492 AD]
Christopher Columbus sets sail from Spain in search of India and ends up landing in the new world half way across the world.
